in um that frees up both time and

ambiguity and misunderstanding are far
less
likely um mapping Transformations are

Transformers um the other big aspect of
has school that really helps both in

you to be explicit about almost
everything you're
doing probably the worst well-known
example of this is IO um it's almost
impossible for a function to have an

talk to AWS or log something to standard
output um then your functions type will
reflect that that means it's impossible

effect the fact that you can't escape
from IO which by which I mean you can't
get rid of that particular type
annotation means that you also can't
ignore it you have to deal with it it's
like a big neon sign that sign saying be
careful both to you and to anyone
reading your code it's not just IO
um has school's conceptual equivalent to
nulls is always represented in the
function's type and you have to deal
with a potential lack of value before
you can get at the actual data which
means no more null pointer errors the
coroller to that is that if a function
type doesn't say it might return
something then you'll definitely get a
usable value back so not only do you not

single object e
reference um same principle appes other
types of Errors they're always
represented in the type you have to deal

and error handling are just regular
values um but we can go even further

producer the way we need it um the
actual implementation isn't important
here what's interesting is the type
signature essentially what we're doing
is putting constraints on where in the
code we can make a CALA produc
first constraint monad resource M says
that you can only make one in a context
that can allocate and clean up resources
the second one monid reader RM says that
you can only make one in a context that
provides access to a readon environment
and the last two say that the readon
environment has to contain enough
information to configure cafka and it

respectively um one nice side result of

about the sort of things you need from

it wouldn't be able to access something

of all both the implementation and the

do try to do something or use something
you're not supposed to you know
immediately um now that I said this was
about the human side of H I want to
reemphasize that what the explicitness
and the expressiveness and the
consistency of has schol really gives
you at the personal and the team level
is confidence when you ask yourself am I

cases are stated explicitly with types
and in most cases they're dealt with for
you automatically bu those
types when you're trying to think
through the mechanics of how to solve a

you rarely end up second guessing
whether you're using the correct thing
or whether you're using the thing
correctly
and when you read code that somebody

this the answer is usually
yes um because most high school code
works by directly stating what you're

and those three things confidence in
your code in yourself and in your team
allows you to be making progress almost
all the time but even in high school
sometimes you need to go back and rework
something um in most languages
refactoring code is laborious it's Error
prone and it's mentally
tiring you have to keep large chunks of

track all your side effects both
internal and external for example
changing a Shar shared variable or
making a database call um you have to

on and you have to track all your edge

that you were previously
covering even with languages that Prov
had a lot of support for this Java and
intell for example large scale
refactoring is often seen as too time

un to be
undertaken our refactoring in has school
by contrast is enjoyable it's easy it
lacks most of the entirely Justified
paranoia that you usually get in other
languages it's fairly common for my team
and I to rewrite large critical regions
of code and for those to work the first
time they pass the
compiler the cause of that is a

type system functional Purity mutability
and a few other minor niceties but
what's important is that when you put
those all those things together it
removes the fear and the risk you stop

currently making will box you in in the
future and once you're comfortable
working like that refactoring stops
being something that you avoid and
instead becomes just another tool in
your toolbox you become much more
comfortable writing something you know
will need to be reworked or okaying
similar work from your colleagues
because that re rework isn't going to be

architecture in particular is one of

the Consultants got to
it um now designers will often tell you

naturally guides you to the correct way
